Award.AwardTitle: Separation Science and Technology as a Platform for SusChEM: Recovery of Critical Materials and Resources from Solutions and Wastes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET- 1446444
American Institute of Chemical Engineers
PI: Darlene Schuster

The PI proposes a 1.5-day symposium during the upcoming 248th American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting (August 10-14) in San Francisco. The symposium will provide a discussion forum for Separation Science and Technology (SST). This symposium is a follow-up to an NSF co-funded symposium held at the 2012 Fall ACS Meeting entitled ?Ensuring the Sustainability of Critical Materials and Alternatives?.

The overall objectives of the currently proposed symposium are to:
1. Bring into focus crosscutting research and education needs in SST associated with the sustainable recovery and recycling of critical materials and (e.g. metals) and resources (e.g. phosphorous) from liquid and solid wastes including impaired water (e.g. seawater, brackish water, brines and domestic/industrial wastewater), mine tailings and electronic wastes.
2. Communicate these research and education needs to the broader SST community of scientists, engineers, policy makers, business leaders and entrepreneurs.

The symposium will contribute to the advancement of separation science and engineering (SSE) and its application to the sustainable supply of the critical materials and resources to build the sustainable products, processes, technologies, farms and industries of the future by inspiring a new generation of scientists, engineers and students to enter this field.

AIChE will develop and maintain a website that will be neutrally branded and dedicated to the subject of critical materials. It will serve as a repository for relevant materials from this symposium and potential future symposia. The website can link to other sites with pertinent information. The AIChE will permanently have the workshop materials maintained for dissemination. This website will not only make materials available to the research community but also serve to inspire and engage the next generation scientists, engineers and policymakers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 1.5 day symposium/workshop entitled “Separation Science and Technology as a Platform for SusChEM (Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering and Materials)” [referred to henceforth as “SST for SusChEM”] was held August 12-13, 2014 in San Francisco, CA, co-located with the 248th ACS National Meeting.  This is the second in a targeted series of critical materials workshops sponsored by National Science Foundation, Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (NSF CBET).  Grant 1446444 (“Separation Science and Technology as a Platform for SusChEM: Recovery of Critical Materials and Resources from Solutions and Wastes”) supported the registration and/or travel expenses of some of participants.  The grant also covered registration and travel expenses as well as wages for those who organized and provided on-site support for the workshop.

 

The first workshop, “Ensuring the Sustainability of Critical Materials and Alternatives” was held on August 21, 2012 at the ACS national meeting in Philadelphia and brought together engineers, material scientists and chemists from academia and industry to identify areas where more research is needed.

 

The current (second) workshop, SST for SusChEM, brought together 47 attendees from academia, industry, government/national laboratories and professional organizations (AIChE and ACS), 22 of which were speakers, to build on the findings of the first workshop by identifying education gaps as well as remaining research gaps.  The workshop organizing committee included:

 

  • Gretchen Baier, Dow Chemical
  • Mamdou Diallo, KAIST/Caltech
  • Catherine “Katie” Hunt, Dow Chemical (Retired)
  • Bruce Moyer, ORNL
  • Seyi Odueyungbo, Chevron
  • Eric Peterson, INL
  • Darlene Schuster, AIChE

 

The SST for SusChEM workshop served to discuss the research and education needs for advancing the role of separation science and technology (SST) in the sustainable energy, water and materials nexus. A major focus of discussion was on the use, re-use, extraction and recovery of critical materials and resources (e.g. metals and nutrients) from non-traditional sources including impaired water ad liquid wastes (e.g. seawater, brackish water, brines and domestic/industrial wastewater) and wastes (e.g. mine tailings and electronic wastes).  SST for SusChEM included a total of five topic sessions, each included speaker presentations followed by a panel discussion.  The topics were:

 

  1. Recognizing Criticality and a Call for Action:  Waste as Untapped Source of Valuable Materials
  2. Re-engineering Mining and Extractive Metallurgy:  Green Mining
  3. Purifying Impaired Water:  Resource Recovery and Water Reclamation
  4. Reclaiming Precious and Rare Earth Metals:  From Urban Mining to Recycling
  5. Converging Separation Science and Technologies for Materials Sustainability:  Research and Education Needs

 

Speakers included:

 

  • David T. Allen, University of Texas at Austin
  • Corby Anderson, Colorado School of Mines
  • Diana Bauer, U.S. Department of Energy
  • Paul Bohn, University of Notre Dame
  • John L. Burba, Simbol Materials LLC
  • Mark Caffarey, Umicore USA Inc.
  • Mamadou Diallo, KAIST and Caltech
  • Yves Gnanou, King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)
  • Bert Hamelers, Wetsus
  • Yoshiaki Kawajiri, Georgia Tech
  • Alex H. King, Critical Materials Institute, The Ames Laboratory
  • Bruce Moyer, Oak Ridge National Laboratory
